Chapter 17: The Bodhisattva Ground on Making Offerings to the Three Jewels

Such immeasurable merit and virtue, embracing immeasurable Brahma merit and virtue,

Many people refer to parents, spouse, children, relatives, family members, servants, kings, ministers, brahmins, elders, neighbors, friends, insiders, outsiders, men, women, the poor, the rich, those who suffer, those who are happy, teachers, preceptors, those with the same teacher or preceptor, those who live together, those who practice the same Dharma, those who study the same, those from the same country, those with the same name, those with the same surname, up to those with wrong views and those of the lowest caste. Benefiting and making offerings means that if a bodhisattva respectfully offers clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, and dwellings to a Buddha or a Buddha stupa, and makes offerings with various flowers, ointments, incense, scattered incense, music, banners, canopies, lamps, and light, and praises the immeasurable merits of the Tathagata, prostrates with the five limbs, circumambulates to the right three times up to immeasurable times, and also offers gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, shells, amber, agate, and ornaments for the body such as bells, up to a single coin, a single thread, or a single grain of rice, this is called the bodhisattva's benefiting and making offerings.

The most excellent offering means that if a bodhisattva makes offerings to the Buddha and the Buddha's stÅ«pa, makes offerings of benefit, makes offerings constantly, makes offerings of fine things, makes offerings of what is seen, makes offerings of what is not seen, makes offerings by oneself, makes offerings by others, makes offerings with a sincere mind, makes offerings with a joyful mind, and makes offerings with a mind of patient acceptance and delight, and dedicates such offerings towards supreme perfect enlightenment, this is called the most excellent offering.

Pure offerings means that if a bodhisattva personally makes offerings to the Buddha or a Buddha stupa, it is not out of arrogance or contempt that they make others do it. They are not negligent, but diligently and sincerely make offerings with a pure mind, not to gain the faith and respect of the ruler, not to obtain offerings from kings, ministers, elders, or householders, and not to show off their own merits. To uphold and make offerings means that if a bodhisattva, whether with their own wealth or seeking from others, makes images or stupas of the Buddha or the Buddha's stupa, whether one, two, up to hundreds of thousands, innumerable myriad koá¹­is, in each stupa, in front of each image, they respectfully bow, and with good flowers, incense, music, lamps, jeweled necklaces, banners, and canopies, they make offerings to them, and do not seek anuttarÄ samyaksaá¹ƒbodhi or the path of the Buddha because of these offerings.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not use their own wealth or seek the wealth of others, and make this vow:

'If the sentient beings in Jambudvipa are able to make offerings to the Three Jewels of Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, from the four continents up to the trichiliocosm, and the sentient beings in the innumerable worlds of the ten directions make offerings to the Three Jewels with the highest, middling, and lowest [intentions], I will wholeheartedly rejoice in them.'

'By these causes and conditions, may all sentient beings attain the perfect enlightenment of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.'

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the mind of loving-kindness for the duration of a cow's resting, and likewise for compassion, joy, and equanimity. All conditioned phenomena are impermanent, without self, without pleasure, and without purity. They deeply contemplate the subtle and wonderful merits of nirvÄá¹‡a, and recollect the Buddha, Dharma, Saá¹ƒgha, giving, precepts, and heavens, and so forth. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas make offerings to the Three Jewels for six reasons: first, because the field of merit is unsurpassed;
second, because they know kindness and repay kindness;

When bodhisattvas wish to receive the bodhisattva precepts, they should observe the preceptor. If they possess eight qualities, they should follow them to receive the precepts.

They reprimand and admonish those who speak of what is not the Dharma, and are able to endure all the suffering of slander, beating, scolding, and harm, as well as those who violate the precepts due to greed, anger, and delusion, and those who are lazy. Their speech is gentle and never coarse, and they always think of sentient beings, wishing to bring them peace and happiness.

They are well-versed in skillful means and teach and transform sentient beings.
They know the antidotes to the afflictions of sentient beings, and their minds toward all sentient beings are impartial, without any distinction of high or low, noble or humble.
Their six sense faculties are complete and their deportment is dignified.
They do not believe in slander, engage in subtle conduct and pure conduct, do not boast about themselves or look down on others, and do not outwardly display flattery for the sake of material gain.
Abandoning the mind of greed, jealousy, and stinginess, if one obtains benefits for oneself, one should first recommend others.
The mind should always be single-minded and without negligence. Seeing others obtain benefits, one should be joyful as if it were oneself.
Knowing contentment and having few desires, one should only keep the six items. Apart from the six items, one should give whatever one obtains.
Always encouraging others to confess their transgressions, showing them how to remember and skillfully knowing the methods of repentance.
Skillfully able to care for and nurse the sick and suffering.
Never proclaiming the faults of the Sravaka canon or Bodhisattva canon.
If one is fully endowed with such dharmas, one is qualified to be a preceptor.
After the Bodhisattva-mahasattva has received the precepts, if the preceptor is sick, he should serve as an attendant. If the preceptor is not sick, he should follow the teachings and act.

He should give rise to a reverent and respectful mind, welcome and bow to the preceptor, stand to the side, offer him clothing, food, bedding, medicine, and Dharma language in accordance with the Dharma, and act in accordance with the Dharma without wavering, truthfully confessing any offenses committed.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who receive the bodhisattva precepts are of two kinds:
First, the wise;

Bodhisattvas cultivate the four immeasurables: friendliness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
The four immeasurables are of three kinds:
First, having sentient beings as object;
Second, having dharmas as object;
Third, having no object.

As for having sentient beings as object, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the mind of friendliness, contemplating all three kinds of sentient beings: those who are experiencing happiness, those who are experiencing suffering, and those who are experiencing neither suffering nor happiness.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the mind of friendliness, contemplating those who are experiencing happiness to increase it, contemplating those who are suffering to end their suffering and give rise to happiness, and contemplating those who are neither suffering nor happy to end their suffering and happiness and attain nirvÄá¹‡a. The signless means to abandon the signs of sentient beings and dharmas, and to increase the mind of loving-kindness. This is called the signless.
As with loving-kindness, the other three immeasurables are also like this.

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the immeasurables based on sentient beings, one should know that this mind is no different from that of non-Buddhists, and is shared with Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.

One kind is the suffering of birth.
There are also two kinds:
First, the suffering of not obtaining what one seeks;

There are also three kinds:

Second, suffering caused by anger;
Third, suffering caused by sleepiness;
Fourth, suffering caused by agitation and remorse;

There are also six kinds:

Fourth, the suffering of guarding;

There are also seven kinds:

There are also ten kinds:
First, the suffering of having food but no utensils;

Fifth, the suffering of not obtaining light when seeking it;ğŸ”½Sixth, the suffering of not obtaining servants when seeking them;

There are also nine kinds:
First, all suffering;
Second, great suffering;
Third, all self-suffering;

As for all suffering, one obtains present suffering due to causes from the past.
As for great suffering, it is like the suffering of hell that sentient beings experience over immeasurable eons.
As for all self-suffering, it is like the suffering in the realms of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods.

Suffering of not abiding in accordance with the Dharma refers to suffering such as plotting to harm others but not accomplishing the task and instead suffering the consequences, like the great suffering of craving food and drink later, like the suffering of craving desire, anger, and delusion, like suffering caused by evil actions of body, speech, and mind, and like the suffering of remorse caused by violating precepts.

Transforming suffering refers to suffering such as the current king's body transforming to become a slave in the next life, like the current parents, brothers, sisters, and wife transforming to become enemies in the next life, and like the current great wealth transforming to become poverty in the next life.

Suffering of not having mastery refers to suffering such as wanting to attain long life, wanting to attain beauty, wanting to attain a noble family, wanting to attain wealth and nobility, wanting to attain physical strength, wanting to attain wisdom, and wanting to eliminate enemies but not being able to obtain one's wishes.

The suffering of harm is like people in the world seeking to end poverty but not being able to end suffering, while those who have left the household life seek to destroy afflictions but are unable to destroy suffering. These are called the one hundred and ten sufferings.
Bodhisattvas contemplate these kinds of suffering and increase their great compassion.

second, the suffering of experiencing karmic retribution;ğŸ”½third, the suffering of conditioned existence;

Bodhisattvas are always called greatly compassionate for four reasons:
First, they contemplate the causes and conditions of sentient beings' suffering, which are profound and difficult to understand;
Second, they cultivate for immeasurable lifetimes;
Third, they cultivate with utmost sincerity;
Fourth, because of their utmost sincerity, they do not spare their bodies and lives for the sake of sentient beings.

For these four causes and conditions, they are able to endure hardship for sentient beings, accept suffering, and take on a suffering body. Therefore, bodhisattvas are called pure great compassion, and pure great compassion is called the stage of the TathÄgata.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate these one hundred and ten matters. All bodhisattvas cultivate and accumulate them all for the sake of sentient beings and increase great compassion.

In this way, bodhisattvas are able to contemplate the characteristics of sentient beings and phenomena and give rise to great compassion, but they are unable to contemplate the characteristics of the signless and give rise to great compassion. Therefore, they are not called great compassion;
The TathÄgata is able to possess these three kinds, and is therefore called great compassion.

Because bodhisattvas cultivate great compassion, they attain physical tranquility and attain mental tranquility. For these causes and conditions of physical and mental tranquility, they are able to destroy the afflictions of sentient beings, abide in the pure stage, the stage of the only child, and love sentient beings as if they were their own children.

For the causes and conditions of great compassion, they diligently practice austerities for the sake of sentient beings without any regret or retreat in their minds, just as when the path of the Å›rÄvakas realizes the four truths and experiences the bliss of the uncontaminated, the cultivation of compassion by the bodhisattvas is also like this.
The cultivation of compassion by the bodhisattvas is solely for the sake of sentient beings, not for their own cultivation of the causes and conditions of compassion.

The bodhisattvas, not sparing even their own lives or external wealth, cultivate the causes and conditions of compassion, abandoning their bodies and receiving bodies, never violating the precepts of the TathÄgata, able to attain samÄdhis that are difficult to attain, and able to attain wisdom that is difficult to attain.
Therefore, the TathÄgata said in the sÅ«tras:

It should be said that it resides in great compassion.
It is immeasurable, boundless, and incalculable, thus it is called great compassion.

Bodhisattvas cultivate these immeasurable minds to attain present happiness, to enable sentient beings to be free from suffering and distress, to attain immeasurable and unsurpassed merit, and to adorn anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
Chapter 18: The Thirty-Seven Factors of Enlightenment, Part of the Bodhisattva Ground, The Eighteenth What is meant by the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's sense of shame and conscience?
There are two kinds of shame and conscience:
First, the nature;
Second, the causes and conditions.

As for the nature, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas themselves know that what they have done is not in accordance with the Dharma, and they fear the evil retribution, thus giving rise to a sense of shame and conscience.
As for the causes and conditions, if bodhisattvas are afraid that others will know about the evil they have done, they will give rise to a sense of shame and conscience.
The sense of shame and conscience by nature is not attained through causes and conditions, like the nature of bodhisattvas.
The cultivation of a sense of shame and conscience by bodhisattvas is attained through causes and conditions, like the causes and conditions of the Eightfold Noble Path.
There are four kinds of shame and conscience:
First, giving rise to a sense of shame and conscience for doing what should not be done;
Second, one should be ashamed and embarrassed for not doing what should be done;
Third, one should be ashamed and embarrassed for doubting in one's mind;
Fourth, one should be ashamed and embarrassed for concealing one's faults for fear of others knowing.
What is meant by bodhisattva?
A sattva is called courageous and fearless.

The nature of a bodhisattva has the power of courage. Because of this courageous nature, one can subdue afflictions and not follow one's mind. One can endure various sufferings and fears. Although there may be fears, they cannot shake the bodhisattva's good dharmas and adornments. This is called the power of the courageous nature of a bodhisattva. Therefore, it is called bodhisattva.
There are five causes and conditions for the courageous nature of a bodhisattva:
First, various sufferings of birth and death;
Second, sentient beings engage in various evil deeds;
Third, for immeasurable lifetimes, one endures immeasurable suffering in order to benefit sentient beings;
Fourth, one firmly upholds the bodhisattva precepts with utmost sincerity;
Fifth, one listens to and receives the profound Dharma with utmost sincerity.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have five causes and conditions for enduring great suffering and hardship for the sake of sentient beings without feeling sorrow.
First, because they have great courageous strength;
second, because they cultivate the absence of sorrow;
third, because they diligently apply skillful means and are vigorous in their efforts;
fourth, because they have the strength of wisdom;
fifth, because they single-mindedly cultivate the mind of compassion.
How do bodhisattvas understand worldly texts?

Bodhisattvas are well-versed in worldly techniques. They know characters, know sentences, know phrases, and know meanings. They single-mindedly uphold them with a harmonious mind and mouth. This is called bodhisattvas knowing the Dharma and knowing the meanings.

Because they know the Dharma and know the meanings, they are able to explain them to others. Because of the causes and conditions of explanation, the wisdom of the Dharma and the wisdom of meanings increase. This is called the wisdom of hearing and the wisdom of contemplation.
Because of the causes and conditions of this wisdom of hearing and contemplation, the factors that assist in attaining enlightenment increase.
What is meant by bodhisattvas knowing the world?
The world is of two kinds:
First, the world of sentient beings;
Second, the world of the vessel.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe the world of sentient beings, therefore the sÅ«tra says:
Those who practice austerities in the world experience birth and death, but do not know birth and death and cannot attain liberation.
The TathÄgata skillfully knows the world of sentient beings, therefore the sÅ«tra says:
Sentient beings have five turbidities:
First, the turbidity of lifespan;
Second, the turbidity of sentient beings;
Third, the turbidity of afflictions;
Fourth, the turbidity of views;
Fifth, the turbidity of the eon.
Now, the lifespan of humans does not exceed a hundred years, this is called the turbidity of lifespan.

Now, sentient beings are unable to provide filial care to their parents, teachers, preceptors, Å›ramaá¹‡as, and brÄhmaá¹‡as, do not practice in accordance with the meaning, are not afraid of the present and future worlds, do not enjoy giving, do not delight in merit and virtue, and do not enjoy receiving precepts and diligently upholding them, this is called the turbidity of sentient beings.

Now, because sentient beings give rise to afflictions, they kill their parents, commit sexual misconduct with their mothers, sisters, and other relatives, create evil causes and conditions for sentient beings, possess bows, arrows, swords, staffs, spears and halberds, and there are many sentient beings who lie, engage in divisive speech, harsh speech, and idle chatter. When such immeasurable evil and unwholesome afflictions arise, this is called the affliction-disturbance.

Now, sentient beings regard what is not the Dharma as the Dharma and what is the Dharma as not the Dharma, and they speak of what is not the Dharma as the Dharma and what is the Dharma as not the Dharma. Because of their views and speech, they destroy the true Dharma and increase heretical teachings. Immeasurable sentient beings cultivate heretical views. This is called the view-disturbance.
Just as in the evil times and among evil sentient beings, there are three kinds of internal evil kalpas that arise:
First, the internal kalpa of famine;
Second, the internal kalpa of pestilence;
Third, the internal kalpa of warfare. This is called the kalpa-disturbance.
This is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of the world of sentient beings.
